Description: Shoulder sherd of Attic black-figured pottery closed vessel, possibly an amphora; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of horse and rider to right (horse's hindquarters with part of tail, body and part of neck with added white mane; rider's body in added red cloak, arm and right leg remaining); at left break, undetermined motif, possibly krotala.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Venit sees the animal as a mule and suggests that the image depicts the Return of Hephaistos.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 463, no. B788)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0076) (Phase 1)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
